page.title: 07Harris Tweed(contd).
page.content: It is hard work, but a weaver can do three or more tweeds in a week. Working steadily a tweed could be done in about ten hours, and one good thing about this is that a weaver can work the hours he wants to, take his time, or do all the work at the beginning of the week and have the rest of the week free. Most of the tweed is exported to foreign countries, the majority going to America, and at the moment, because the value of the dollar is so high, they can afford to buy more so the mills are getting plenty of orders. It is ironic that it is when the economy is low, the better off the weavers are, but then, it works the other way too.
